2.38.text:
Are American college campuses “rape cultures?”
Are they dangerous places where sexual assaults

8.17.text:
against women are happening at an alarming
rate?

11.38.text:
According to many gender activists, academics
and politicians, the answer is yes.

18.02.text:
Here’s what the Vice-President of the United States,
Joe Biden, said in 2014.

23.12.text:
“We know the numbers: one in five of every
one of those young women who is dropped off

28.05.text:
for that first day of school, before they
finish school, will be assaulted,

32.48.text: will be assaulted in her college years.”

34.88.text:
Let’s take a closer look at the Vice President’s
claim.

38.74.text:
Rape is a horrific crime, and rapists are
rightfully despised. We have strict laws against

44.50.text:
sexual assault that everyone wants to see
enforced. But, while rape is certainly a very

49.60.text:
serious problem, there is simply no evidence
of a national campus rape epidemic, and there’s

55.40.text:
certainly no evidence that sexual violence
is a “cultural norm” in 21st century America.

61.96.text:
In fact, rates of rape in the US are very
low and they’ve been declining for decades.

67.82.text:
Why would it be any different on a college
campus? Where, then, does the 1 in 5 rate

72.47.text:
that Vice President Biden cites come from?
Well, it turns out it comes from a study conducted

77.94.text:
over the Internet at two large universities,
one in the Midwest and one in the South.

83.18.text:
The survey was anonymous, no one’s claims were
verified and terms were not clearly defined.

89.26.text:
In round numbers a total of 5000 women participated.
Based on their responses, the authors,

95.22.text:
not the participants, determined that 1000 had
been victims of some type of “non-consensual

103.94.text:
And voila! From one vaguely worded, unscientific
survey we suddenly arrive at “a rape culture

110.85.text:
on college campuses.” Tellingly, the study
authors have since explicitly stated that

116.81.text:
it is “inappropriate” to use their survey
to make that claim.

120.95.text:
Much more comprehensive data from the U.S.
Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) estimates

127.13.text:
that about 1 in 52.6 college women will be
victims of rape or sexual assault over the

133.42.text:
course of four years. That’s far too many,
but it’s a long way from 1 in 5.

139.20.text:
The same BJS data also reveal that women in
college are safer from rape than college-aged

145.70.text: women who are not enrolled in college.

148.12.text:
But the truth doesn’t serve the purposes
of feminist activists or vote-seeking politicians.

154.08.text:
Lies work much better. And the 1 in 5 claim
is tantamount to a lie. Here are just a few

160.99.text:
examples of what this lie has wrought.
At Scripps College, Pulitzer-Prize winning

166.09.text:
commentator George Will was disinvited from
giving a speech. The reason?

171.61.text:
He had dared to question the “rape culture” mantra
in a column he wrote.

176.77.text:
At the all-women Wellesley College, students
demanded that the administration remove a

181.60.text:
campus sculpture of a sleepwalking man wearing
only underpants. Why? Well, because the image

188.15.text:
of a nearly naked male could “trigger”
memories of sexual assault for victims.

193.39.text:
According to Harvard Law professor, Jeannie
Suk, students now ask teachers not to include

199.06.text:
questions about rape law on exams for fear
that such disturbing questions might cause

207.21.text:
And at Brown University, students were so
traumatized by a debate on the subject of

212.68.text:
campus sexual assault that activists organized
a “safe room” equipped with coloring books,

218.66.text:
Play-Doh, calming music, and a video of frolicking
puppies.

223.48.text:
No less absurd are the attempts by colleges
and legislators to cure this non-existent plague.

229.56.text:
In California and New York, students
now have to live by so-called “Affirmative

234.36.text:
Consent” laws. The California law says that
affirmative consent by all parties must be

240.45.text:
“ongoing throughout a sexual activity,”
while the New York law says that “silence

245.54.text:
or lack of resistance, in and of itself, does
not demonstrate consent.”

250.34.text:
Confused? Pity the poor college students who
have to figure this out. If it wasn’t so

256.16.text:
serious, it would be laughable. But it’s
not funny to a growing number of young men

261.40.text:
who find themselves accused of sexual assault,
publicly shamed and then brought before campus

267.05.text:
judicial panels that are guided by rape-culture
theory. In such proceedings, due process is

273.28.text: an afterthought: it’s guilty because accused.

277.62.text:
But here’s the best way to prove that the
1 in 5 number is phony. Ask yourself this question:

283.60.text:
Would you send your daughter to
a place for four years where there was a twenty

287.80.text:
percent chance she would be raped or sexually
assaulted?

293.08.text:
Good rarely, if ever, comes from lies. The
one in five “rape culture” lie is no exception.

299.76.text:
I’m Caroline Kitchens of the American Enterprise
Institute for Prager University.
